_**Looney Tunes: Back in Action**_ is a 2003 American [live-
action/animated](/wiki/Live-action_animated_film "Live-action animated film")
[comedy film](/wiki/Comedy_film "Comedy film") directed by [Joe
Dante](/wiki/Joe_Dante "Joe Dante"). It is the third feature-length live-
action/animation hybrid film to feature _[Looney Tunes](/wiki/Looney_Tunes
"Looney Tunes")_ characters, after _[Who Framed Roger
Rabbit](/wiki/Who_Framed_Roger_Rabbit "Who Framed Roger Rabbit")_ (1988) and
_[Space Jam](/wiki/Space_Jam "Space Jam")_ (1996). The plot follows [Daffy
Duck](/wiki/Daffy_Duck "Daffy Duck") and [Bugs Bunny](/wiki/Bugs_Bunny "Bugs
Bunny") (both voiced by [Joe Alaskey](/wiki/Joe_Alaskey "Joe Alaskey")) as
they help aspiring [daredevil](/wiki/Stunt_performer "Stunt performer") Damian
"D.J." Drake, Jr. ([Brendan Fraser](/wiki/Brendan_Fraser "Brendan Fraser"))
and [Warner Bros.](/wiki/Warner_Bros. "Warner Bros.") executive Kate Houghton
([Jenna Elfman](/wiki/Jenna_Elfman "Jenna Elfman")) find the "[blue
monkey](/wiki/Blue_monkey "Blue monkey")" diamond in order to prevent the evil
Mr. Chairman ([Steve Martin](/wiki/Steve_Martin "Steve Martin")) of the [Acme
Corporation](/wiki/Acme_Corporation "Acme Corporation") from using it to turn
mankind into monkeys that will manufacture his products; the group also
attempts to rescue D.J.'s father ([Timothy Dalton](/wiki/Timothy_Dalton
"Timothy Dalton")), an actor and spy who has been captured by Mr. Chairman.

The film was theatrically released on November 14, 2003 with mixed-to-positive
critical reception.[3][4] However, the film was a [box office
bomb](/wiki/Box_office_bomb "Box office bomb"),[5][6] grossing $68.5 million
worldwide against an $80 million budget.[2] This was the final film to be
scored by composer [Jerry Goldsmith](/wiki/Jerry_Goldsmith "Jerry Goldsmith"),
who died less than a year after the film's release. This was also the final
film to be produced by [Warner Bros. Feature
Animation](/wiki/Warner_Bros._Animation "Warner Bros. Animation").

## Plot

Tired of playing [second banana](/wiki/Double_act "Double act") to [Bugs
Bunny](/wiki/Bugs_Bunny "Bugs Bunny"), [Daffy Duck](/wiki/Daffy_Duck "Daffy
Duck") demands his own cartoon from [Warner Bros.](/wiki/Warner_Bros. "Warner
Bros."), but is promptly fired. Aspiring [stuntman](/wiki/Stuntman "Stuntman")
DJ Drake is asked to escort Daffy off the studio lot, but the ensuing chase
leads to the [Batmobile](/wiki/Batmobile "Batmobile") demolishing the studio
[water tower](/wiki/Water_tower "Water tower"). DJ is also fired in the
process, and returns home with Daffy hitching a ride, discovering his father,
[action film](/wiki/Action_film "Action film") star, Damian Drake, is actually
a [secret agent](/wiki/Espionage "Espionage"). Damian instructs his son to
travel to [Las Vegas](/wiki/Las_Vegas "Las Vegas"), find his associate Dusty
Tails, and gain the mystical "blue monkey" [diamond](/wiki/Diamond "Diamond"),
but he is shortly thereafter captured by the [Acme
Corporation](/wiki/Acme_Corporation "Acme Corporation"), led by the childish
Mr. Chairman. DJ and Daffy head for Vegas. Meanwhile, Bugs' routines fall
apart without Daffy, so "Vice-President of Comedy," Kate Houghton, is sent to
rehire Daffy or face being fired herself. Bugs informs Kate of the situation,
so they steal Damian's spy car, and pursue DJ and Daffy.

In Las Vegas, DJ and Daffy meet Dusty in a [casino](/wiki/Casino "Casino")
owned by Acme operative [Yosemite Sam](/wiki/Yosemite_Sam "Yosemite Sam").
Dusty gives them a strange playing card, but when Sam attempts to kill them,
they flee in the spy car with Bugs and Kate. The spy car, which can also
[fly](/wiki/Flying_car_\(aircraft\) "Flying car \(aircraft\)"), crashes in the
Nevada desert. The group eventually stumbles upon [Area 52](/wiki/Area_51
"Area 51"), run by a woman called 'mother', who informs them of the situation,
and plays a video recording, which reveals that Acme intends on using the blue
monkey to transform mankind into monkeys to manufacture their products, before
turning them back into human beings to purchase them. [Marvin the
Martian](/wiki/Marvin_the_Martian "Marvin the Martian"), imprisoned in the
facility, escapes and leads a group of fellow alien inmates to obtain the
playing card, but the heroes escape. Seeing that the card has [Mona
Lisa](/wiki/Mona_Lisa "Mona Lisa")'s face on it, the group conclude they must
view the painting in the [Louvre](/wiki/Louvre "Louvre"), located in
[Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris").

At the Louvre, they discover that the card contains a viewing window, and
looking through it, the window reveals that the Mona Lisa has a map of
[Africa](/wiki/Africa "Africa") hidden beneath. [Elmer Fudd](/wiki/Elmer_Fudd
"Elmer Fudd") appears, and, revealing himself as an Acme operative, chases
Bugs and Daffy through the gallery for the card whilst Kate is kidnapped by
Mr. Chairman's [bodyguard](/wiki/Bodyguard "Bodyguard"), Mr. Smith, to obtain
a photo of the African map. DJ rescues Kate. Elmer is disintegrated by Bugs
after jumping out of a pointillism artwork. Bugs and Daffy reunite with DJ and
Kate, and they leave Paris.

DJ, Kate, Bugs, and Daffy travel to Africa, meeting Granny, Sylvester, and
Tweety, who escort them to the ruins of a jungle temple where they find the
blue monkey. Granny and company reveal themselves to be Mr. Chairman, Smith,
and the Tasmanian Devil in disguise. Mr. Chairman uses a [disintegration
gun](/wiki/Duck_Dodgers_in_the_24%C2%BDth_Century "Duck Dodgers in the 24½th
Century") to transport himself and the heroes to the Acme headquarters where
he forces DJ to give him the diamond, when Damian is revealed to be his
prisoner.

Marvin is sent to place the blue monkey on an Acme satellite which will emit
an energy beam around the world to turn everyone, except Mr. Chairman, into
monkeys. DJ and Kate rescue Damian from a death trap, whilst Bugs and Daffy
pursue Marvin into space. Bugs is incapacitated, prompting Daffy to become
[Duck Dodgers](/wiki/Duck_Dodgers "Duck Dodgers"), in order to destroy the
blue monkey. The transforming energy beam only strikes Mr. Chairman, turning
him into a monkey.

Bugs and Daffy return to Earth, where Daffy discovers the whole adventure was
staged to make a film. However, Bugs promises Daffy they will be equal
partners, but just as Daffy's luck seems to be improving, he is flattened by
the Looney Tunes iris, where [Porky Pig](/wiki/Porky_Pig "Porky Pig") attempts
to close the film with "That's all folks!" only for the studio to shut down
before he can finish, and he tells the audience to go home.

## Production

A follow-up to _[Space Jam](/wiki/Space_Jam "Space Jam")_ was planned as early
as the film's release. As development began, _Space Jam 2_ was going to
involve a new [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball") competition between
the Looney Tunes and a new villain named Berserk-O!. Artist [Bob
Camp](/wiki/Bob_Camp "Bob Camp") was tasked with designing Berserk-O! and his
henchmen. [Joe Pytka](/wiki/Joe_Pytka "Joe Pytka") would have returned to
direct and [Spike Brandt](/wiki/Spike_Brandt "Spike Brandt") and [Tony
Cervone](/wiki/Tony_Cervone "Tony Cervone") signed on as the animation
supervisors. However, [Michael Jordan](/wiki/Michael_Jordan "Michael Jordan")
did not agree to star in a sequel. According to Camp, a producer lied to
design artists, claiming that Jordan had signed on in order to keep
development going. Warner Bros. eventually canceled plans for _Space Jam
2_.[10]

The film then re-entered development as _Spy Jam_ and was to star [Jackie
Chan](/wiki/Jackie_Chan "Jackie Chan"). Warner Bros. was also planning a film
titled _Race Jam_ which would have starred [Jeff Gordon](/wiki/Jeff_Gordon
"Jeff Gordon"). Both projects were ultimately cancelled. Warner Bros.
eventually asked [Joe Dante](/wiki/Joe_Dante "Joe Dante") to direct _Back in
Action_ , having had previous success with _[Gremlins](/wiki/Gremlins
"Gremlins")_ (1984) and _[Innerspace](/wiki/Innerspace "Innerspace")_ (1987).
In the early 1990s, Dante wanted to produce a biographical comedy with
[HBO](/wiki/HBO "HBO"), called _Termite Terrace_. It centered around director
[Chuck Jones](/wiki/Chuck_Jones "Chuck Jones")' early years at Warner Bros. in
the 1930s. On the project, Dante recalled "It was a hilarious story and it was
very good except that Warner Bros. said 'Look, it’s an old story. It’s got
period stuff in it. We don’t want that. We want to rebrand our characters and
we want to do _Space Jam_.'"[11]

Dante agreed to direct _Back in Action_ as tribute to Jones. He and
screenwriter [Larry Doyle](/wiki/Larry_Doyle_\(writer\) "Larry Doyle
\(writer\)") reportedly wanted the film to the "Anti-_Space Jam_ " as Dante
disliked how that film represented the _Looney Tunes_ brand and personalities.
Dante said "I was making a movie for them with those characters [_Looney
Tunes: Back in Action_] and they did not want to know about those characters.
They didn’t want to know why [Bugs Bunny](/wiki/Bugs_Bunny "Bugs Bunny")
shouldn’t do hip-hop. It was a pretty grim experience all around." Warner
Bros. hired [Walt Disney Feature
Animation](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Animation_Studios "Walt Disney Animation
Studios")'s [Eric Goldberg](/wiki/Eric_Goldberg_\(film_director\) "Eric
Goldberg \(film director\)"), most known for his fast-paced, Warner
Bros.-inspired animation of the [Genie](/wiki/Genie_\(Disney_character\)
"Genie \(Disney character\)") in _[Aladdin](/wiki/Aladdin_\(1992_Disney_film\)
"Aladdin \(1992 Disney film\)")_ (1992), to direct the animation.

On the film, Dante stated "It's a gagfest. Not having a particularly strong
story, it just goes from gag to gag and location to location. It's not a
particularly compelling narrative, but, of course, that's not where the charm
of the movie is supposed to lie." On the subject of filming, Dante said "[W]e
would shoot each scene three times. First we'd rehearse with a stand-in—a
'stuffy,' we called it. Then, we'd shoot the scene without anything in it;
then, we'd shoot the scene again with this mirror ball in the shot which shows
the computers where the light sources are. Then the animators would go to work
and put characters into the frame. The problem with that movie came when the
studio [executives] started to get tired of our jokes and wanted us to change
them. But, of course, the animation is done to the voices and not the other
way around. It was difficult trying to convince them that you don't just bring
in 25 gag writers and try to write a joke that's short enough to put in
somebody's mouth." Although the production had twenty-five gag writers, the
film has only one credited writer.[12]

Despite being directed by acknowledged fans of the original cartoons, Dante
stated that he had no creative freedom on the project, and called it "the
longest year and a half of my life." Dante felt that he and Goldberg managed
to preserve the original personalities of the characters. However, the
opening, middle, and end of the film are different from what Dante
envisioned.[13]

Goldberg also provided the voices of [Tweety](/wiki/Tweety "Tweety"),
[Michigan J. Frog](/wiki/Michigan_J._Frog "Michigan J. Frog"), [Marvin the
Martian](/wiki/Marvin_the_Martian "Marvin the Martian") and [Speedy
Gonzales](/wiki/Speedy_Gonzales "Speedy Gonzales"). [Brendan
Fraser](/wiki/Brendan_Fraser "Brendan Fraser") provided the voice of the
[Tazmanian Devil](/wiki/Tasmanian_Devil_\(Looney_Tunes\) "Tasmanian Devil
\(Looney Tunes\)") and She-Devil, having impressed Dante with his Taz vocal
impression.

## Soundtrack

This was the final film scored by composer [Jerry
Goldsmith](/wiki/Jerry_Goldsmith "Jerry Goldsmith"). Due to Goldsmith's
failing health, the last reel of the film was actually scored by [John
Debney](/wiki/John_Debney "John Debney"), though Goldsmith was the only
credited composer in marketing materials and the [Varèse
Sarabande](/wiki/Var%C3%A8se_Sarabande "Varèse Sarabande") soundtrack album
only contains Goldsmith's music (although the first and last cues are
adaptations of compositions heard in Warner Bros. cartoons). Debney receives
an "Additional Music by" credit in the closing titles of the film and "Special
Thanks" in the soundtrack album credits.[14] Goldsmith died in July 2004,
eight months after the film's release.

## Reception

### Commercial reception

_Looney Tunes: Back in Action_ was released on November 14, 2003, originally
planned to open earlier that summer. The film grossed $68.5 million worldwide
against a budget of $80 million.[15][5]

Warner Bros. was hoping to start a revitalized franchise of _Looney Tunes_
media and products with the success of _Back in Action_.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] New
animated shorts and [a _Duck Dodgers_ TV
series](/wiki/Duck_Dodgers_\(TV_series\) "Duck Dodgers \(TV series\)") were
commissioned to tie-in with _Back in Action_. The film instead triggered
Warner Bros. to release new TV projects in an effort to re-brand the _Looney
Tunes_ such as _[Loonatics Unleashed](/wiki/Loonatics_Unleashed "Loonatics
Unleashed")_ (2005–2007), _[The Looney Tunes Show](/wiki/The_Looney_Tunes_Show
"The Looney Tunes Show")_ (2011–2014), and
_[Wabbit](/wiki/Wabbit_\(TV_series\) "Wabbit \(TV series\)")_ (2015–present).

### Critical response

Critical response aggregation website [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes
"Rotten Tomatoes") gave the film an approval rating of 57% based on 134
reviews. The site's critical consensus reads: "The plot is a nonsensical,
hyperactive jumble and the gags are relatively uninspired compared to the
classic _Looney Tunes_ cartoons."[3] At [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic
"Metacritic"), the film scored a 64/100, indicating "generally favorable
reviews"[4] _[Chicago Sun-Times](/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times "Chicago Sun-Times")_
movie critics, [Roger Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") and [Richard
Roeper](/wiki/Richard_Roeper "Richard Roeper"), gave the film "Two Thumbs Up";
Roeper called it a "cheerful and self-referential romp blending animation with
live action in a non-stop quest for silly laughs," while Ebert called it
"goofy fun."[16]

The film was also nominated for [Saturn Award for Best Animated
Film](/wiki/Saturn_Award_for_Best_Animated_Film "Saturn Award for Best
Animated Film"), [Annie Award for Best Animated
Feature](/wiki/Annie_Award_for_Best_Animated_Feature "Annie Award for Best
Animated Feature") and [Satellite Award for Best Animated or Mixed Media
Feature](/wiki/Satellite_Award_for_Best_Animated_or_Mixed_Media_Feature
"Satellite Award for Best Animated or Mixed Media Feature").

## Home media release

[Warner Home Video](/wiki/Warner_Home_Video "Warner Home Video") released
_Looney Tunes: Back in Action_ on [VHS](/wiki/VHS "VHS") and [DVD](/wiki/DVD
"DVD") on March 2, 2004. The film was re-released on DVD in separate
[widescreen](/wiki/Widescreen "Widescreen") and [full
screen](/wiki/Aspect_ratio_\(image\)#4:3_standard "Aspect ratio \(image\)")
editions on September 7, 2010. It was also released on [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-ray
"Blu-ray") with bonus features on December 2, 2014.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] A
double DVD and [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-ray "Blu-ray") release, paired with _[Space
Jam](/wiki/Space_Jam "Space Jam")_ , was released on June 7, 2016.[17]
